summary: On November 5, 2019, the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York entered a final judgment against defendant Gregory Rustigian III in a second-degree murder case.  The SEC's complaint, filed in federal court in New York City, alleges that, on August 2, 2016, in the early hours of the morning of August 3, 2017, Alfredo C. Cravens, a bouncer at a New York bar, and Gregory R. "Rustigian" Rustigier, a Mexican national, engaged in a verbal altercation with a group of men at the bar. According to the complaint, after the men left the bar, the defendant allegedly raised his voice and said, “You guys are going to get jumped when you leave this bar.”  The complaint further alleges that after the initial punch, the victim fell backwards and hit his head on the concrete curb.  According to a complaint filed in the United States District Court in Manhattan, the defendants continued to engage in this conduct even after the punch was delivered.  As alleged in the SEC's Complaint, however, that the defendant did not take any steps to check the safety of the victim or to secure emergency assistance.  In addition, the complaint alleges that the defendants did not engage in any aggressive or aggressive conduct.  Instead, they allegedly used a combination of verbal and physical force to cause the victim to fall backward and hit the ground.  Without admitting or denying the allegations of the SEC complaint, the Defendants have consented to the entry of final judgments permanently enjoining them from future violations of the antifraud provisions of Section 17(a) of the Securities Act of 1933 and Section 10(b) the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 and Rule 10b-5 thereunder, and ordering them to pay disgorgement of ill-gotten gains plus prejudgment interest, a civil penalty, and a penny stock bar against each of them.  On November 4, 2018, the Honorable Judge Robert C. Hannan of the New York District Court entered a judgment that permanently enjoins the Defendants from violating the charged provisions of the federal securities laws, and orders the Defendants to pay civil penalties in the amount of $10,000 and $20,000, respectively, for each of those violations. The Court also ordered the defendants to pay a $1,000 civil penalty.  A hearing on November 6, 2018 was scheduled for 11:30 a.m. EST.  Judge Hannan granted the Defendants’ motion for a preliminary injunction, ordered a conduct-based injunction, and ordered a hearing in which the defendants will be
